The canvas was a bit loose in one corner, (which is to be expected with changes in temperature during shipping), but I had no problem straightening it out, tight as a drum, when I applied the keys to the bars in the back. The linen is a nice medium texture. Excellent quality for a good price.

stretched_canvas_reviews.review_desc: Thank you for taking the time to share your candid feedback. We're sorry to hear that these canvases were frustrating for you. Changes in humidity can cause the canvas to slacken at any time, so a canvas that's well-stretched by the manufacturer may be taut in our warehouse and looser when it arrives to you. Although the inevitability of tension changes in stretched canvases is the reason these frames are "keyable" (so they can be tightened as needed), it's not our intention that you ever be disappointed in a Blick purchase. We see that one of our Customer Care Agents has already worked out a solution with you, and we appreciate your time and comments!

Linen is temperamental when it comes to slackening in arid conditions, so you can imagine February is when a lot of artists are dealing with this issue. Although the inevitability of tension changes in stretched canvases is the reason these frames are "keyable" (so they can be tightened as needed), it's not our intention that you ever be disappointed in a Blick purchase. I have no complaints about this canvas. Excellent for a mixed media project, the canvas was stiff and slightly textured, but texture didn't negatively impact the end result. Liquitex is an industry standard for a reason!

I used this canvas to paint a quick little painting for my granddaughter. It's a very firm canvas that my paints took to very well. I really enjoyed using this product and will definitely purchase and use again.

stretched_canvas_reviews.review_title: You'd never know its made out of plastic bottles
stretched_canvas_reviews.review_desc: This canvas feels & paints just like regular regular canvas. I love the fact that is made out of recycled plastic bottles. You'd think it would easily absorb the paint but it totally does. You won't regret purchasing this canvas!

stretched_canvas_reviews.review_title: What a great way to recycle!
stretched_canvas_reviews.review_desc: I am shocked by this canvas. It feels and acts just like fabric but it's recycled bottles! It came pre-primed. The paint adheres well. I really like the overall value and outcome of the painting. I'll definitely be buying this canvas and other recycled material based supplies in the future.

The Liquitex recycled canvas is a great product and I will be purchasing this canvas over the non recycled canvas from now on. The canvas itself is high quality and it produces quality paintings. The paint glides on very smoothly and feels just like a regular cotton canvas.

stretched_canvas_reviews.review_title: Helping the planet one artwork at a time
stretched_canvas_reviews.review_desc: I wasn't expecting the Liquitex Recycled Canvas to be as high quality as it was. I love that it's made from recycled bottles and FSC certified wood, and even the label is recycled content and all packaging is fully recyclable ! It comes already primed which made it easy to get started. It's a bit heavier weight cloth than regular canvas, but I actually liked that better, since I am using a mix of regular acrylic, heavy body acrylic, and some other media on this piece. Unfortunately due to a health issue I have not been able to work on the piece much to show any photos ( it is also going to be a surprise gift). Liquitex has made a great product, one that I will be using exclusively from now on. You can feel good that you're going to create great artwork and also do your bit to help get plastic out of the ecosystem.
This canvas was such amazing quality! It was sturdy and had a little bit of weight to it which I personally prefer. You can definitely tell how well this was made and I'm going to be buying more!

I'm not a huge fan of Winsor & Newton, especially since they've been bought out by the ColArt Group. But I have to admit, their stretched cotton canvas is the best you can get. If you want better quality than this, you'll be stretching your own. My biggest problem with pre-stretched canvas has always been canvas tightness. I like my canvas nice and tight. I don't want it wiggling around while I'm trying to paint. This canvas is relatively tight right out of the package. And it comes with these cool adjustable wedges. These wedges take it to the next level. So if you work on cotton canvas, and you prefer to buy pre-stretched, I highly recommend that you give this product a try.

stretched_canvas_reviews.review_desc: Thank you for your review. We did receive your returned canvases and inspected them to find no pinholes in either size. However, fine linens often have an open weave where light can shine through the priming. In addition, in fine weaves it's not unusual for the priming to penetrate and show white spots on the back of the fabric, but since the canvas has been sized (and the sizing is clear), there is no harm to the linen fibers. Both characteristics are sometimes mistaken for pinholes, but they are not holes and not flaws. Nonetheless, we welcome you to return any item that does not meet your expectations. That's our 100% Satisfaction Guarantee!

alcohol_markers_reviews.product: Prismacolor Premier Dual-Ended Chisel Tip Markers and Sets
alcohol_markers_reviews.review_desc: Well, you can't say that they don't hold up. I purchased my one and only set waaaay back in 1985 from our local Dick Blick (closed over 20 years ago) while attending college. Anyway, a few years back I suffered a stroke which somewhat curtailed my model hobby that started again after I retired. So these past four years I got back into coloring books. Not all the time mind you but just to break the boredom. Then this past month I purchased some adult based coloring books for markers, and that got me to thinking about these markers I had down in my studio cabinet. Lo and behold, they are still quite functional, but I have a few that after reopening the caps, they start to dry out until I put the cap back on and let it rest for a day or two. I think a new set is in the future. Yet, after almost 40 years, I can't complain about a very good purchase.

I already was expecting shipping so i payed the EXTRA $ just to get them shipped. That didn't leave me with a great feeling about ordering from your website ever again. I live in Hawaii, USA. alcohol_markers_reviews.product: Olo Dual-Tip Markers and Sets
alcohol_markers_reviews.review_desc: They are good alcohol markers however the smell is stronger than every other alcohol marker I have (Ohuhu, Copic, Arrtyx, Grabie). They give me a headache. The other brands I did not really notice an issue with the smell being too strong. Especially Ohuhu they win in the least smell category for me. If you have a sensitive nose I would not recommend the Olo's. Especially at how much they cost.

alcohol_markers_reviews.product: Olo Dual-Tip Markers and Sets
alcohol_markers_reviews.review_desc: I wasn't looking for markers, but they were on clearance near the checkouts and I impulsively bought the "autumn" pack. The light colors are nice and soft for building layers. The bullet nibs seem like great quality and hold their shape. I didn't notice any bleeding, I didn't really attempt to blend so cannot speak to that. I didn't know when I bought them that they had replacement cartridges, it's a great idea. Even just the ability to custom build a palette and save some space for on the go is great. I'm going back to buy out whatever other colors I can find if there are any left!

alcohol_markers_reviews.product: Olo Dual-Tip Markers and Sets
alcohol_markers_reviews.review_title: Try a small set. See how you like it. You might be surprised
alcohol_markers_reviews.review_desc: I have to say, these are a great alternative to the more expensive professional marker brand. Comparing the orange Olo to the orange Copic, there was virtually no difference in color. The other thing is that they don't have the heavy alcohol smell that Copics have. The dual tip connection feature is a great idea as well as being able to order handles, connectors and fills. I would highly recommend people purchase at least a small set to get an idea of what they can do. I give it 4 stars because blending wet over wet didn't seem to do anything on various papers.

colored_pencils_reviews.review_title: Leads break and sharpen into nothing
colored_pencils_reviews.review_desc: I use color pencils in most of my work. I use several different high quality Artist brands and I was excited to see Holbein come out with colored pencils because I LOVE my acryla gouache paints by them. These color pencils have a nice texture to them--somewhere in between Caran d'ache Luminance and Faber Castell Poly Chromos. I bought several of these Holbeins and about 4 of them work well for me, like, I love them, but the other 6 break and break and break. I can't even sharpen them--they sharpen into nothing, it's heart-breaking (and EXPENSIVE). I'm very sad and will not be buying these again, I'll stick to more consistent brands.

colored_pencils_reviews.product: Caran d'Ache Pablo Colored Pencils and Sets
colored_pencils_reviews.review_desc: I like these pencils. They layer endlessly and blend well. The white pencil is really nice. However, I have two complaints. First is that some of the colors are very similar to the point that they're pretty much the same color. The purplish red, purple, and purple violet are all basically the same color. The pencils also appear to be magenta rather than purple. They could have added a couple more true purples and pinks rather than have 3 of the same color. I found that many other colors are also similar. I added some photos of my swatch chart, though many of them look even more similar in person. They could have eliminated these duplicates and added a better range of colors, such as true purples, pinks, skin tones, and a wider range of grays and browns. It seems more like a 72 set than a 120 set. My second complaint is that the metallic print on the barrel of the pencil is nearly impossible to read. This makes it extremely difficult to find a specific color. I find myself squinting and moving the pencil around to catch the light in just the right way. Despite these flaws, I am still rating them 4 stars because they are a dream to use.

colored_pencils_reviews.product: Faber-Castell Goldfaber Color Pencils and Sets
colored_pencils_reviews.review_desc: Love the Faber-Castell Goldfaber line of colored pencils. They are slightly harder than Faber-Castell's more expensive Polychromos, so they hold a point better for some detail work, and they're very friction-free on paper. They're not quite as pigmented as the Polychromos line, but they do look good, and they're less expensive. I find them satisfying to use, the colors are nice, and they layer well. The white isn't particularly opaque, but I don't use white. They don't have lightfastness ratings, pigment info or color names on the pencils, but you can buy them open stock (in fact, I did), so I'd consider them student grade.

drawing_pencils_reviews.review_desc: I like the harder pencils for creating a preparatory drawing for watercolor. The harder leads provide the image I will need for watercolor without leaving any graphite dust that would interfere with the watercolor and they also provide a clear image I can follow as I begin to paint. These pencils provide lines that stand up to the preparatory application of water for washes as well as continuing to show just where my piece needs additional attention. The range of hardnesses is also great: from relatively soft for sketching to very hard for the final underdrawing. And like all the other Derwent products they are high quality and a pleasure to use.

drawing_pencils_reviews.review_title: I have and will buy Blacking products again and again
drawing_pencils_reviews.review_desc: These are the best possible wooden pencils you can buy - the erasers actually erase and the lead can be soft or hard - depending on what you choose. I am never disappointed in anything Blackwing!

This is a cynical review, so I'll apologize now. First of all, these are good pencils. We are so inundated with digital technology: social media, short form video, phone notifications all day long. So, I'm rooting for pencil, paper and slow art. We've bought the old Blackwing Palominos and 60Xs and enjoyed using them. Had no problems with breaking leads or splintering cedar. But we paid a pretty penny for these pencils, likely more than they are worth... This is kind of like a special edition candy bar. Decent, but it's the same candy bar with a fancy/funny wrapper. What grade is a particular Blackwing lead? HB? 2H B? number 2? Who knows? I don't. Botanical artists have written blog posts on pencil brands, lead hardness, ability to sharpen and lifespan. They differ about favorite brands, but they agree that brands differ. So, lead grades aren't a precise science. I'll admit that a 2H Hi Uni and a 2H Tombow are different hardnesses. But when you just get a grade of "firm" it seems a bit loosy goosey. And expensive. For comparison, the beloved Tombow Mono is about $1.50 per pencil and you know exactly what you are getting. No pretty boxes or paint finishes, but cheaper, more consistent, and with a long track record. You could spend as much money on a Hi Uni as a Blackwing Era pencil and again you will have a pretty good idea of what you are getting with the Hi Uni. The Blackwings sure are fun to give as a gift, though. They present well and look nice on your recipient's desk. That's the brilliant aspect of the Blackwings. They get people interested in old, analog media. Again, this is great marketing and these are good pencils, but they are pretty pricey for a mystery pencil. So, I wouldn't recommend these to a friend (see below, I had to choose between "yes" and "no"). But I would give a set to a friend if the box design echoed a special event in their life.

My sister has been wanting to get into art, but she is not a big fan of color. I was trying to come up with something that she might like and I remembered a video by Superraedizzle on YouTube where she mentioned how much she loves General's charcoal. Well, if it's good for Rae, it's good for me. My sister has since fallen in love with these! She went from barely every drawing anything to sending me gorgeous portraits every week. She's done characters from her favorite shows, and people she admires like Muhammed Ali and Denzel Washington. It's incredible how quickly she picked up art once we found something that worked for her. These are a great price, and a perfect kit for beginning to work with charcoal. I will never stop recommending General's Charcoal. #sweepstakes

These are probably the smoothest writing carbon pencils I've ever used. And they don't break as easily during sharpening.

6B was not that soft. General charcoal pencils are much better and even cheaper. The reason I tried Wolff was the fact that about 30-50% of General pencils are coming with inside core broken, I guess due to bad handling either before getting shipped or during shipment (like getting badly shaken by the shipping carrier inside of the shipping box without the pencils having enough soft wrapping). I don't have statistics on how many of Wolff are broken, I bought only 2 and one of them appeared to be broken on the second sharpening.

drawing_pencils_reviews.review_title: A bit of history in your hand...
drawing_pencils_reviews.review_desc: I inherited my grandfather's art box about 20 years ago... as he was 96 or so when he died my original Wolff Carbon Pencils are quite short, and _old_. I was thrilled to discover that these are still made, more than 100 years later, if by a different maker under the Wolff brand. Just as smooth, dark, and nice to work with as the originals, and I feel like I'm holding a bit of history... and don't have to wear my grandfather's pencils down any further! #sweepstakes

These Wolff pencils are my first foray into carbon pencil art. I love how smooth they are, and how they're matte, rather than having graphite shine. They also keep their point for a very long time. I do wish the spectrum of these were a bit broader, I'd really enjoy the addition of an F pencil. But these can be lightened with erasers. I used both a Tombow mono eraser and kneaded eraser and found success with both. These are definitely my go to pencils now. #sweepstakes

I used this to make carbon dust for painting/drawing. They work pretty well - smooth and not as crumbly as General's. I also already had a Rembrandt Lyra carbon pencil 2B, which I may like even better for carbon dust. #sweepstakes
Perfect for my drawing course. Smooth shading without grit, easy to carve to a long point.

I absolutely love the way this pencil lays down, very smooth and even. It's kind of waxy so doesnt blend or erase as well as charcoal or pastels but I use it for sketching and with charcoal pencils for more finished drawings. Linear drawing isn't really my thing but it would be great for that. #sweepstakes

This is one of my favorite sketching tools. It is a consistently soft lead, but the large diameter means less breakage. It can be sharpened to a fine point with a standard (hand-held) pencil sharpener for sketching, or shaped with a craft blade or sanding block. It can also be used unsharpened for laying down value in large areas or for bold, expressive lines. Very versatile, consistent, and a good value for the money.

drawing_pencils_reviews.review_title: Great, basic drawing set for a beginner.
drawing_pencils_reviews.review_desc: I am brand new to drawing. I think this is the perfect set for me. The eraser and sharpener work fine. I have no idea what the tortilion or sandpaper paddle are - but I'm sure I will learn. I just wanted a really basic set with pencils, eraser and sharpener. All the other sets had like 18 or 36 pencils, two different kind of erasers, fancy this and that - and its just too overwhelming when I'm such a beginner. I decided to get this very basic set to get me started and it will do just fine. I got: 2B, B and 2H in the graphite pencils, and then in the charcoal pencils I got 6B ex soft, HB hard and 4B soft.

drawing_pencils_reviews.review_desc: I am a college teacher and ordered these for my 101 level drawing class. They are just perfect for that purpose, everything they need is in this nice little kit. These are also good for advanced students to use.

drawing_pencils_reviews.product: General's Drawing Class Essential Tools Kit
drawing_pencils_reviews.review_desc: I used these kits in a drawing class I teach. They are a great value and contained the basics I was looking for. I use this brand often when buying drawing utensils for my own use as an artist.

drawing_pencils_reviews.product: General's Drawing Class Essential Tools Kit
drawing_pencils_reviews.review_title: great way to get started again
drawing_pencils_reviews.review_desc: I decided to get back into doing some sketching and this is just the right product to get started with.

drawing_pencils_reviews.review_title: these are perfect for packing in the mountains.
drawing_pencils_reviews.review_desc: These are absolutely. Perfect for taking out in the mountains with the sketch pads I got from you. After sketching I can put them to larger canvases in oil! Thank you for this group.

drawing_pencils_reviews.review_title: Good product for the price; good customer service
drawing_pencils_reviews.review_desc: These pencils seem of good quality, and are certainly a good buy for the price; they come with an eraser and sharpener to seal the deal. I was in need of more drawing pencils and since I don't really know my "preference" as to hard or soft, this seemed like a good range without too many unnecessary options. I look forward to continuing to use these; so far they seem just fine in quality and craftsmanship. These pencils were the only item of my order to arrive at my house in the shipment, though the invoice said nothing about a backorder or separate shipment. I was missing two other items from my order. I contacted customer service regarding the missing items and received a prompt reply and apology. The missing items were shipped quickly at no additional cost or inconvenience to me. I would certainly consider purchasing items from Dick Blick again based on this customer service experience. Thank you, DB!

Since I just began to write, I did not know what kind of pencils I should buy. On one hand, I did not want to spend much. On the other hand, I wanted to buy some pencils that would help me to improve my drawings. I this this set was a good deal. Not only the pencils are good, but also is the eraser and sharpener.
I've been through countless dozens of these pencils over the years. They do exactly what they were intended to do, and they do it perfectly. I hope they never stop making these! #sweepstakes

drawing_pencils_reviews.review_title: My favorite pencils, a must have!
drawing_pencils_reviews.review_desc: These Layout pencils are excellent! Very smooth to draw with, and they make a dark line while keeping a point fairly well. Erases cleanly, maybe better than a 6B does normally. The thick core offers tremendous versatility, especially if sharpened with a knife, and can accomplish both fine and broad lines, and a range of tones. The best pencil for sketching on the go, as all I need is this one pencil, my pocket knife to sharpen it, and maybe a bit of grey eraser! It's also excellent for finished pencil drawings! I can do a whole drawing with just this pencil, but sometimes I do like combining it with a General's Draughting one (for the preliminary sketch) and the Carbon Sketch (for the final, darkest black notes). General's makes very high quality pencils—made in the USA!—and I can't recommend their products enough! #sweepstakes
Good quality .....

drawing_pencils_reviews.review_title: These are the only pencils I want to use forever
drawing_pencils_reviews.review_desc: I will be honest I am not the best at drawing, but I do take tons of notes, and if you're a person who finds yourself writing a lot this pencil is amazing! I do not like to push very hard on the paper because it hurts my hand after awhile, but I do not have to press hard at all with this pencil! Very effortless writing, I am going to school to become a teacher and these will definitely be a staple at my desk! I love them!

Bought this as a made in the US option for the imported Ebony pencil by Prismacolor. This one works really well. It's the right level of soft. I'm not an artist, though. I just dabble. But this is more than sufficient for my needs. I love General's brand.
The GO-TO pencils for layout on paper as well as linoleum, and even canvas. Easily erased and they come sharpened which sets them up for perfect subsequent sharpening.
This is pretty much the only pencil I use, just the right amount of softness, very responsive.
Simply the best drawing pencil I have ever used. Nice rich black, soft. The only drawback is that you have to sharpen it often.
Mostly useful for laying in and underdrawing.

drawing_pencils_reviews.review_title: A great pencil for shading- good price & quality for student
drawing_pencils_reviews.review_desc: I buy these every year for my high school Art 1 students to shade their self-portrait projects with...it's a great shading pencil that can create very strong darks. The graphite is soft and easy to blend. A great product and great price!

I am always pleased with the quality and price of the Staedtler Mars brand. The weight of these pencils is perfect. The points sharpen beautifully. The graphite added to these pencils is just the right amount to add a subtle sheen and drama, but does not overpower the beautiful colors. Bravo Staedtler, you have done it again!
Thoroughly pleased with the watercolor pencils. I particularly like the shading differences that can be obtained by varying the amount of water. Very nice set.
Love these pencils! The colors are brighter than my other tinted graphite pencils and so pretty.

drawing_pencils_reviews.review_title: I absolutely love these pencils . They are fantastic !
drawing_pencils_reviews.review_desc: These pencils are wonderful to add texture to your drawing or painting. The tinted colors are very calm and beautiful. I am surprised that there are hot many fantastic reviews to this product.

These are of reliable quality and are the best all around pencil for the elementary Art classroom. My students like them also, frequently asking to take one back to their regular classroom.

graphite_reviews.review_title: Enjoying my pencils! Just what I wanted

Great quality

graphite_reviews.product: Dixon Ticonderoga No. 2 Soft Black Pencil Set
graphite_reviews.review_desc: These are my favorite pencils. I put one in each art supply kit for my students as their basic drawing pencil for almost every course. I love the soft lead - you can get a great range of values. Excellent for beginners to keep from being overwhelmed with all the different types of drawing pencils. #sweepstakes

graphite_reviews.product: Dixon Ticonderoga No. 2 Soft Black Pencil Set
graphite_reviews.review_desc: These make very good drawing pencils. Good range of tones achieved ranging from maybe an F to a 2B. Are they the smoothest pencil I've ever used? No. But they are decent and have a little feedback which I like. So you can spend roughly .40 a pencil buying a Ticonderoga or spend $1.50-$3.00 for an "ART" Pencil. It's not the Pencil, it's the person using the Pencil. Plus, they are readily available in many locations but I like to support Dick Blick.

graphite_reviews.product: Dixon Ticonderoga No. 2 Soft Black Pencil Set
graphite_reviews.review_title: If heaven lived in a Pencil, it would be here
graphite_reviews.review_desc: Excellent black pencils. We used for drawing before watercolour or to add detail to finished watercolours. Was fuzzy in the electric pencil sharpener- but maybe that was the sharpener's fault.

graphite_reviews.product: Dixon Ticonderoga No. 2 Soft Black Pencil Set
graphite_reviews.review_desc: These are the best #2 pencils around, I don't know what it is but nothing else will do it for me.

graphite_reviews.product: Dixon Ticonderoga No. 2 Soft Black Pencil Set

graphite_reviews.review_desc: Don't bother buying other pencils. These are the best. I use mine to carve wizard faces in them to give to my music students. (See photo.)

graphite_reviews.review_title: These are the only pencils I use.
graphite_reviews.review_desc: For all things pencil, I use Ticonderoga. They are easy to shade with for students and pros alike. AND THE SMELL. Go on, sniff your pencil and compare it with the woody smell of a Ticonderoga. < 3

graphite_reviews.review_title: I would buy this product again
graphite_reviews.review_desc: Using in a drawing workshop. Recommend by teacher. Very pleased
I buy these pencils for my middle school art classroom. They are high quality and easy to recognize as belonging to the art room with their characteristic blue and white design.
Work great on wooden yard art projects, projects and quick sketches.

graphite_reviews.review_title: I would buy this item again and again
graphite_reviews.review_desc: This is a excellent drawing pencil

graphite_reviews.review_title: The One Pencil to Rule them All
graphite_reviews.review_desc: I discovered these pencils in a dark room of my photo class. They are such nice pencils so I decided to snatch a few. I have always wanted to buy a pack of my own so when I finally got my own studio I decided that the time has come! The design is much more interesting than a regular yellow pencil, the lead stays sharp for a looong time and the erasers work flawlessly (not wearing down too quickly). I use these pencils for simple sketching or jotting down notes or even measurements on woodwork. They're just really good for every day use! I splurged a bit on the 72 pack because I often lose pencils or use up the eraser too quickly, but I can say these will last me a long time.

graphite_reviews.review_title: Best pencil for schools, art class
graphite_reviews.review_desc: I have taught art for 11 years with ages 3-14. I have always been on a quest for the best pencil. This pencil is hands down the best. I think I've had maybe 5 pencils that had the lead break once even after being used by 500 students a week in my art room. That's five pencils for the whole school year. Never shred or splinter. I only put new pencils out after the mid term break because they got too short. I do have the students use little metal hand held sharpeners, not traditional ones. The amount of money saved on pencils is fantastic.
I love how these pencils look. And, they are quite functional and write fairly smooth. I think these pencils are a good buy for the price.
These pencils are the best for the price. Not the cheapest
I have bought expensive drawing pencils and still go back to these.
I love these Staedtler Rally #2HB pencils. I have bought the more expensive drawing pencils and keep coming back to these.

I use these pencils as "loaners" in my art classes. They are readily identifiable and when used with Pentel eraser caps are favored by my students. I almost never "lose" one because everyone knows they'll be here to use if they come back... also they're easy to recognize as "art" pencils. A really good buy when purchased in discount quantities.

graphite_reviews.review_title: Try them and find the one you like best
graphite_reviews.review_desc: I gave my husband this set for Christmas. We loved comparing the mark making of each pencil and both have different favorites.
I have always wanted to try these pencils and this is a perfect way to do it. I like them all!

graphite_reviews.review_title: These Saved Me As A Writer
graphite_reviews.review_desc: I have always had the best cursive handwriting calligraphy old English style. It just came natural to me since i was born. With being a writer, I depend on good pencils. Or my trusty keyboard. I say never get back to where I was God blessed me with skill. so, this was in my pencil box, and I absolutely have to use it ALOT. I have small hands to and can't draw a straight line, but this pencil makes Me feel I am in control. Not the stroke. Yes, i recommend this for little kids or people like me!
A perfect pencil for beginners.
everyday work

These beginner pencils are a staple in my K-5 art room. They work well because of their thickness with small hands to large hands. I keep them stockpiled along with pink pearl erasers as the eraser tip wears out sooner than the pencil. I wish they were available without the eraser tip so the metal that supports the eraser wouldn't scratch the kids papers once the eraser starts wearing out.

The pencils were for preschoolers to makes imprints (drawings) on foam sheets for watercolor prints. The wider pencil was great both because not all preschoolers have strong fine motor skills to grip a pencil and because the lead is also wider, which created a wider imprint for lines on the foam. Ticonderoga is an excellent brand. The only downside was that the pencils did not fit in my sharpeer so I had to carve tips with a knife.

I teach art to kids from grades k-2. I see 200 kids each day and we used to go through a lot pencils! I like the Beginner size because they do not need to be sharpened as often due to the thicker lead. They are also less likely to break, they have a bigger eraser that does not snap off, and the kids do not seam to press down as hard when they are drawing.
They may make these for writing, but they're brilliant for drawing. The leads don't break easily, they take a great point, and they make a lovely silvery line.

I've been a carpenter for 45 years and was always irritated that flat carpenter pencils made such a wide mark letting accuracy suffer. Standard pencils are too weak to mark rough wood surfaces and break the points just when you need them. Then I married a kindergarten teacher and began to use her student's pencils. She now makes me buy them myself but the Ticonderoga Beginner 's Pencil is the best in the business for my business and Blick's has the best deal. Just hide them from your grand children as they can have a tendency to walk off.
I have used these pencils before. If you sharpen them with an old fashioned pencil sharpener, they last forever between sharpening! Great price too!
I really am a big fan of "General Pencils"!

I use these Cedar Pointe #1 for writing and amateur drawing. The line is dark, smooth and consistent comparable to a good 2B pencil but with good sharpening and point retention. It erases well with the attached eraser, even better with a separate eraser. The finish is smooth to the touch, not sticky and not slippery.

graphite_reviews.review_title: Will definitely buy when I run out …
graphite_reviews.review_desc: I ordered 3 boxes of 12. Only able to find box of 4 at stores. LOVE LOVE LOVE these pencils - lead, raw wood, and eraser.
Solid pencils. Nice scent when sharpened.

These pencils are wonderful! I have tried a number of the nicer pencils and several had nice lead and wood but none have an eraser close to the Generals. I work remodeling houses and often make marks on finished surfaces and need to cleanly erase them when I am done.

I love that these are paint free and more sustainable. That's hard to find and exactly what I've been looking for in an everyday pencil for my kids to use. Worth the price as cheaper pencils often sharpen oddly as the lead is crooked and less durable.

As a homeschooling family, we go through a LOT of pencils. Everyone gives these a solid thumbs up. The quality is obvious; and the fact that they are US made means a lot to us. Thank you for carrying General's!

I am loving these pencils! I like that they're made of natural wood and no paint. The led is good quality and the construction is solid, feels nice to hold and the wood is pretty. Call me fancy but I didn't mind paying a little extra for really nice pencils.

graphite_reviews.review_title: Beautiful Pencils, smooth for writing and drawing
graphite_reviews.review_desc: Number 1 pencils are becoming rare. These are high quality sustainable cedar pencils with perfectly centered smooth cores that sharpen nicely. Good looking too, with the black ferrule and eraser. Eraser works well.

graphite_reviews.review_title: I will certainly buy these No. 1 pencils again.
graphite_reviews.review_desc: These No. 1 pencils are difficult to find and I am very pleased with them.
pencils are of good quality, draw smoothly, and are easy to sharpen
These work well, and are economically priced. I also like that the yellow is slightly different from most pencils, so I can tell that they are from my class.
These yellow Staedtler pencils are a great but. Their quality is good for the price. And they write fairly smoothly for the price.
The pencils are of good quality, the triangular shape helps to develop the correct grip in children.

My students love these pencils. They are smooth to hold, and the triangular shape feels refreshing on the writing fingers (not scratchy), and the white eraser is my most favorite part- because I prefer my students not erase mistakes (only to strike through). I tell them I'd rather see their "processes of thinking" and they can earn credit. If it's gone, then I can't give credit. I tell you this because the white erasers, strange as it is, for some reason, lesson their desire to erase!! AND-THEY ARE CLEANER if they do erase!! Thank you!

graphite_reviews.review_title: I would buy this product again
graphite_reviews.review_desc: I bought this for a special needs adult. Triangular shape made it easier for the person to hold.

We have used it for 10 years and will keep use it!

graphite_reviews.product: Paper Mate Mirado Black Warrior Pencil Set

graphite_reviews.product: Paper Mate Mirado Black Warrior Pencil Set

graphite_reviews.product: Paper Mate Mirado Black Warrior Pencil Set
graphite_reviews.review_desc: Not chocolate, this pencil. A premium pencil without the premium price. As nice as the pencils that cost more each than what these cost per dozen? No, but closer than anything else I've tried in the price category. It writes smoothly, with a lot of "feel" to the lead. It is fairly soft even for an HB lead, and has a very consistent texture, unlike many where there occasional hard spots in the lead. The line produced is dark, smooth and consistent. A great pencil in this price range.
My clients loved the pop of color that these added!
Wonderful combination of colors and excellent pencil quality! Super fun for kids and adults!

Used for doing geometry constructions

oil_pastels_reviews.review_title: The Absolute Best Oil Pastels on the Market
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I recently picked out 12 oil pastels from the open stock at a Blick store for my birthday, for every 3 my mother bought for me the price went down. I was able to build my own set. Not only do these have the absolute best pigment quality and smooth creamy texture but their size and shape reduce significantly the pain I usually have when drawing/painting from my rheumatoid arthritis- these are perfect for anyone with hand or wrist pain, not to mention you save money as the Grands last about 8-10 times as long as a regular sized oil pastel. Nobody can beat Sennilier when it comes to quality of their products, and no one else has such a wide variety of colors to choose from! I use these to sketch sculpture ideas (I can make the sketching look much more 3D w/these), in mixed media and encaustic projects, with OMS and wood turpentine for paintings, and even to decorate some of my porcelain sculptures. There is nothing to compare to these- my only problem is since I didn't buy these as a set with a box, I am struggling to find the right container to store them in so they won't break or rub off on each other too much.

These oil pastels are so creamy and rich in colour as i9 drag it across paper or use my oil linen or canvas. You can rub and blend the colours with your hand or fingers, create new colours with blends. Fantastic! Now i am using Sennelier Oil Pastels over acrylics and even oil paint. I am very confident with the oil pastels upon other colors and different surfaces. A pure joy to explore now.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Pentel Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I reobtained Pentel last year because they were on the vegan list on Double Check Vegan (which is now crossed off), but looks like it is said otherwise in the Q&A. However, I'll not let my ethical bias get in the way of this review. First off, people are right about the smell. There is a gas-like smell to them (a smell I don't remember a while back when I had my first set many years ago). While it may not have bothered me too much, this may trigger headaches in others. It states long-lasting fade-resistant color. From my personal experience with testing and other artists who have done their own tests at home, I would NOT recommend these for commission works because most of the colors will not last long. I personally would keep these for sketchbook use and other fun things (If anything, you can do what I do and sell prints that'll last longer than the original art). Anyway, depending on weather, the blendability is a bit on the waxy side, but it'll definitely be waxy and crumbly if it's cold (goes the same with other alike oil pastels). The day was warmer when I worked on the female cardinal and had an easier time blending in colors than I did with the male cardinal, which was a bit cold in my room during the time of painting. The colors aren't deeply pigmented hence you can see the burnt sienna acrylic underpainting a bit on the white part of her belly. You can also see through the background of the purple fish. The amount of layering for these projects felt limiting, and it definitely didn't help when the underpaintings somewhat ended up a bit smooth than I wanted. They may not be Neopastels nor layer as much as a few other brans, but I still feel I can do plenty enough with these. Again, my ethical bias aside, I had fun doing these painterly pieces and I recommend them as starters (if you really insist on softer oil pastels that are better on your wallet than Neopastels, Holbein, and Sennelier, try either Lightwish, Mungyo or another alike brand).

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Pentel Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: Full disclosure, I am an art teacher at the high school level. In addition, the artwork provided with this review is not my original design, I found an image online to use as a reference. That said, these are some really nice oil pastels at the student level. Some colors struggle to show up on darker paper hence why I took off a star. I wish I could give half points as I would rate these 4.5 out of 5 and not just a 4. I actually prefer using these on regular construction paper, I believe my image is done on Tru-Ray brand and is done on a light gray color. I found I liked them a bit less on heavily textured pastel papers like mi-teintes. Best used with high pressure and letting the pastels do most of the blending work. My examples was done completely using the 36 color set. This set is proof great work can be made with materials that don't have to break the bank.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Pentel Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: We're sorry these oil pastels didn't work out for you, but of course we were happy to accommodate your return. We encourage you to reach out to our Product Information Department for assistance in choosing an alternative. They're available weekdays 8am to 5:30pm CST at 1-800-933-2542, and they're happy to help!

oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I bought several brands of oil pastels for my grandkids and me to compare. All were of high-quality. This basic set compares quite nicely, and the parents were happier to have the smaller sets for the kids to use in their limited space.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Blick Essentials Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_title: I would buy it again but I'd supplement with pentel pastels.
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: Using it with 4th and 5th graders, drawing, blending, layering, and scraping.Good value but the pastels ae thicker than the Pentel pastels and the black and brown pastels do not glide the way the other colors do.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Blick Essentials Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: Thank you for taking the time to share your candid comments. We never like to disappoint, and we're sorry to hear that the smell of the pastels was bothersome to you. We appreciate your business, and your feedback is helpful and always welcome. If we can be of assistance, please don't hesitate to give our Customer Care Team a call at 1-800-723-2787.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Blick Essentials Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: Use these in conjunction with oils.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Blick Essentials Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_title: I always have oil pastels in my studio
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I use these in collage and mixed media. They are great to have on hand.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Blick Essentials Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_title: I would buy this product again
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I have purchased these oil pastel sets before to use in a demonstration my students did in front of the school board, and now the students are using them in the classroom. I have purchased more sets twice now because I like them so much. It is a nice way for each student to have their own set of oil pastels, and they are small enough to store easily. The color is nice, and they last a long time (we've been using our for about a year now, and they're still going strong, although I did buy more white and black). I only gave them 4 stars out of 5, though, because they have a bit of a weird smell and they are hard to slide in and out of the box. I made velcro-closure wrappers for mine, which was an extra step. I hope I win the #sweepstakes

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Blick Essentials Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: Bought for my granddaughter 's BD. A good basic set.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Caran d’Ache Neoart 6901 Wax Oil Pastels and Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I love this color. These are harder more opaque with layers . Feels smooth in my older hands. I love them.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Caran d’Ache Neoart 6901 Wax Oil Pastels and Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: Nice black . Smooth on paper good for details.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Caran d’Ache Neoart 6901 Wax Oil Pastels and Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: Hard but smooth on paper. Got several. White is opaque.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Caran d’Ache Neoart 6901 Wax Oil Pastels and Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: Arrived unbroken. Beautiful color. Just glides across paper very smooth. Are hard but pigmented good lines and details.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Caran d’Ache Neoart 6901 Wax Oil Pastels and Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I absolutely love the NeoArt crayons. The colors are luscious, they are easy to use and compliment my Neocolor 1s and Lumience Pencils beautifully.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Caran d’Ache Neoart 6901 Wax Oil Pastels and Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_title: I would buy in open stock again.
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: #sweepstakes I was very curious about this new product from Caran d'Ache and I had to buy the entire 48 collection. I didn't have time to work with the oil/wax sticks for long, I just played with them a little bit, just to get an idea of how they feel and how I could integrate them into my mixed media art. So far I like them. I think they are what they say they are, a combo of oil and wax "pastels" (more % of wax than oil IMO), with good coverage, with vivid colors and some earthy ones included in the full set, clean pigments and excellent lightfastness. I think that they are close to the Neocolor I series in how they work, but with even better lightfastness, if that is even possible. For example, I saw that the ultramarine in the Neoart series is marked LF I (excellent), whereas the same pigment ultramarine in the Neocolor I is marked only as LF II (good), so I might choose the Neoart one to work on a piece that I would like to sell, just to be extra sure. My advice would be to buy several open stock sticks first and play with them before you commit to bigger sets, they are not cheap!

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Caran d’Ache Neoart 6901 Wax Oil Pastels and Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I am so excited about this product! I'm familiar with almost every art material made by Caran d'Ache. They've been one of my top 3 favorite brands since the 90s. These new Neoart pastels are one of my favorite things they've ever done! These are not the same as the Neoart crayons made 10-15 years ago. Those were a different texture and water-soluble. These are waterproof. Like seriously, perfectly waterproof. The texture is almost exactly like Neocolor, but with an even easier laydown, better blending and an even shinier, richer finish when rubbed smooth. The colors can absolutely appear to glow! I hope they expand the color range to match Neocolor II or Luminance, but do not replace Neocolor with these. They are similar but still very different products, and I would really miss the Neocolor! I plan to use these along with both types of Neocolor and my Luminance pencils. They all work great together! These are fantastic for sketching, and I'll have fun using them in sketchbooks and journals. They're also perfectly capable of making a pastel painting worthy of display. They lay down smoothly, layer well and blend nicely, without being smeary or muddy. It's really nice that they're waterproof and don't smudge as easily as Neopastel. They really are perfect for journals! I just want to see more colors!

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Faber-Castell Goldfaber Studio Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_title: I should have gotten a higher quality
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I haven't used this medium in years but I really remembered them being smoother to work with then what I'm experiencing with these. These don't blend well at all. They don't get that oil painting depth either. As a kid I used craypas and that's what I'd go to in the future for an affordable option instead of these or treat myself to some of the really nice Sennelier Blick offers. Worth it.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Faber-Castell Goldfaber Studio Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: These were perfect for my kids who are exploring oil pastels. Lots of vibrant colors and a great price.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Faber-Castell Goldfaber Studio Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: The oil pastel set is a gift for a young artist. Beautiful colors, nicely packaged!

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Faber-Castell Goldfaber Studio Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: Thank you for reaching out! Although this oil pastel is student grade, it's not one we expect to be as you have described. Please consider getting in touch with our Product Information Department for further assistance. They can be reached at info@dickblick.com or 1-800-933-2542 between 8am and 5:30pm CST Monday through Friday, and they're happy to troubleshoot!

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Faber-Castell Goldfaber Studio Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: Definitely easier peeling wrapper and not as greesy as some other brands. More colors would be cool

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Faber-Castell Goldfaber Studio Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: Smooth and easy to use!

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Faber-Castell Goldfaber Studio Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_title: Creamy, blend well, Polychromos Pencils work on top.
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: These oil pastels are really nice. They are creamy and blend easily. I used a Colour Shaper to blend and it worked well. Pastel wipes easily off the silicone tip. The 36 set has a nice assortment of colors including a number of good colors for skin tones. The sticks are much larger than my trusty Pentel Oil Pastels - both longer and at least double the size in diameter. Sticks seem a bit softer than the Pentels. I tried them out on a piece of Strathmore Acrylic paper which has a nice linen surface giving plenty of tooth for the oil pastel. The paper also provided a nice textured finish. The Faber-Castell Polychromous Pencils will work on top without sinking into the oil pastel. That's nice for some finish line work. I bought these for the color palette harmony with other products in the Faber-Castell line. The colors between products match giving a seamless color palette for mixed media projects.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Faber-Castell Goldfaber Studio Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I wish Dick Blick allowed editing of previous reviews. I bought these for plein air studies and sketches, and the nice size case & sleeve (which fit in my small backpack & won't fall open while I'm walking) and wrote the previous review after only sampling the colors and without wiping off the surface of the sticks first. Though they did not show a white surface haze, like some waxy student brands when you first get them, they did have a somewhat hard surface layer that wiped right off, and now they really blend and behave quite nicely for a student brand, and are soft enough to allow dabs of impasto color on top of other layers, which is really wonderful & a pleasant surprise. At least so far (it's winter), they are not affected by heat going places with me in the car, as some other more expensive brands are, so they will be just perfect for what I got them for. I am going to wear out the lovely light blending colors way too soon, though ... fortunately, at the price Dick Blick sells them for, I will just buy more sets when colors run out. My 4 stars consider the price of this product. Of course, they are not better quality than Senneliers (which I gave a low review to because in my area, they simply melt into unusable goo), which are almost 6 times the price, but are a solid 4 stars compared to other student brands. I should have used them more before writing the other review!

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Faber-Castell Goldfaber Studio Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I bought the smallest set just out of curiosity, because they were a brand I hadn't used yet. I have used just about every other artist and student grade oil pastel sold in the US, and find they all have qualities that make them useful. However some stand out from the herd,and some don't. For me, these don't. The Faber Castell brand is very reliable,and these pastels have nothing really wrong with them. But, to me, they are not outstanding in any way compared to other brands in the student category. They are okay. I only bought the 12-piece set, and can only comment based on that. The dark colors would be hard to tell from an artist grade pastel. They seemed to lay down pretty smoothly and opaquely. The lighter tints were obviously waxier in texture and don't have the level of pigment that you would want for opacity. Other than that, the price per set is affordable, and these would be okay for beginning students, or for sketchbook use. I am neutral about recommending them - like I said, they are OK but not special. For what it's worth, if you are a beginner or need to save money, I would recommend the super-cheap Pentel oil pastels over these . Despite their price and student grade rating, they are quite nice in terms of pigment load, soft texture and range of colors.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Faber-Castell Goldfaber Studio Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I bought these for quick plein air sketches, and they will be okay for that. They do allow me to seamlessly integrate my Faber Castell Polychromos pencils over them, or FC Albrecht Durer watercolor pencils for underpainting, as *most* (but not all) of the colors are good matches with those pencils, but they are quite hard and do not blend as well as other student brands. I think they'd be very frustrating for someone just starting in oil pastels. I would recommend Cray Pas Expressionist over these for beginners in this wonderful medium of oil pastel.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Winsor & Newton Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: Rich color, smooth application. Will go back to this product for sure for more colors and other mediums!

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Winsor & Newton Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: Pretty decent oil pastels for a good price.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Winsor & Newton Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: Definitely soft and greesy but great colors. Wish the wrap was paper and easier to tear

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Winsor & Newton Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: The tin box containing these oil pastels are a bit flimsy. Opening the box for the first time, I was intrigued by how the sticks were covered in a layer of oil (check image) and had to wipe them off. I then made some swatches on the Winsor and Newton pastel paper (check images). Some good points: These oil pastels are soft and blendable, but not soft enough to layer over other soft oil pastels in my experience. Bad points: Compared to other artist grade oil pastels, the opaqueness of these sticks is inferior. Their coverage is also patchy and inconsistent (comparable to the expressionist line, just softer), most ostensibly seen with the Medium green stick. It might be because of the paper I was using, but for me so far these pastels have been underperforming as supposedly artist grade oil pastels. Unless they improve this product, I don't see myself returning to it. #sweepstakes

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Winsor & Newton Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_title: AP NonToxic, Artist Grade Pigments, Lightfast, Sturdy tin
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I purchased the 30 set to use as a travel and art class set. The tin with higher quality artist grade pigment + Lightfast with the non-toxic AP rating was a plus. Pros: AP label - so nothing known to be toxic. Soft but not too soft - i.e. not gooey lipstick soft. Blend well, 30 set has a good range of colors for blending. Pigmented. Mix cleanly. White is quite decent. Packed in a sturdy travel tin. Sticks are identical in size to Sakura Cray-Pas Expressionist. Did a small test drawing on vellum cardstock. Used my mini Clay Shapers to blend and clean up the edges which worked well. Cons: Made in China - hopefully W&N supervises the manufacturing closely to maintain their quality standards.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Faber-Castell Grip Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_title: Yes - I will purchase these again
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I use it as a drawing prize gift for my watercolor class I get rave comments on how easily these oil pastels blend They like the case The colors are beautiful

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Faber-Castell Grip Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_title: I will purchase this set again
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I teach an Art class and my students prefer this set due to the fact that it is in it's own plastic snap lid carry box !

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Faber-Castell Grip Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: Needed these for a school project, and the value was great. They are as expected and were a great addition to the supply shelf.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Faber-Castell Grip Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: As oil pastels go, these are rather dry and have more the feel of a soft crayon than a pastel. Blendability was poor just due to how hard they were. They didn't work for what I wanted. A good alternative for crayons, but not really good as oil pastels.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Faber-Castell Grip Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: Really like these Faber Castell Oil Pastels - 24 ct. Like their workability and especially the the case they come in. Because they are thicker, they don't break as easy as some of the other brands. And although they are pricier, I would but again.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Faber-Castell Grip Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_title: I would buy this product again.
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I really like the case the pastels are in. It makes it easy for the students to put the pastels away and keeps them organized. It also separates the pastels so the colors don't contaminate each other and even when turned upside down, the pastels stay locked in place. The hard case and handle also make for easy distribution. The faceted sides of each pastel also keep them from rolling off the table.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Faber-Castell Grip Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I use these for my art classes and really like the plastic box with the handle for kids to use. They are easily placed back in place and each child feels as if they are getting special supplies. The pastels stand up to constant use and the colors are well chosen for children's artwork.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Faber-Castell Grip Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I use these pastels with my K-8th grade students for a variety of projects. They are easy for the younger students to hold, do not roll off the table, and produce great results. I would say they are in the middle of the soft-hard spectrum. Nice color variety in the larger set. The plastic storage container is a huge plus-- it is very sturdy & has a hold-tight slot for each color. The kids have a much easier time finding the color they're looking for, and seem to do a better job of taking care of the pastels. No more mounds of small pieces heaped into a box!!! Last year I purchased 12 of the larger sets, and I used only 6-- one per table lasted the whole year!!! I highly recommend these!

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Faber-Castell Grip Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I was so happy to find a class pack as I buy it for my Reggio- inspired children's centre. It is a fantastic deal. I bought these oil pastels before in a regular pack to let the children try it first. When offered a variety of mediums for art, they all wanted these pastels. It is chinky and easy to hold and the colours are bright. After using these pastels for few months, the children are refusing to use regular crayons :) I will buy these pastels for them over and over again.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Sakura Cray-Pas Specialist Oil Pastels and Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: Nice and smooth, good color.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Sakura Cray-Pas Specialist Oil Pastels and Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: The strength of this particular product is that it is stiff and is good for drawing. The edges make for good lines. Good pigment load. Not as gooey as the student level, and I think it's a better oil pastel than them. However, unless you use a thinner, I have found them not to blend as well and cover an area. Artwork tends to be more like drawings. Which is fine. That's why I bought this set. Good stuff.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Sakura Cray-Pas Specialist Oil Pastels and Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: An Artist friend of mine recommended these Oil Pastels. I love how vibrant they are and they layer well. They will no doubt work with the softer OPs I use. I see these for base layering. I am totally inexperienced so I will have to reserve judgement. Since they are on the hard side, they crumble, so I took a point off for that.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Sakura Cray-Pas Specialist Oil Pastels and Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I like the square shaped sticks and the richness of the colors. I was looking for something a little creamier and was a bit disappointed. These are only slightly creamier than the Expressionist OPs but my disappointment is minor. I usually don't put down more than two layers, nor do I use them for impasto techniques, but rather spread them and rub them in with my fingers or rubbing stumps. For that reason, extreme creaminess is not that important to me, and I get more mileage out of my OPs. Also, I'm too cheap to splurge on Holbein or Sennelier OPs. I will slurge on Holbein individual sticks as I use up my favorite colors, since the Specialists are not available in open stock...another disappointment. I'd expect any professional grade material to be available in open stock. Not a huge disappointment as the sets are very well priced, but who needs a ton of less used colors when you only need a couple. Overall, I'm very pleased with these #blicksweepstakes

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Sakura Cray-Pas Specialist Oil Pastels and Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_title: Yes 10 years from now I will buy some more.
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I just use these for layout. They last a long time and they do not dry out. They work well for how I use them.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Sakura Cray-Pas Specialist Oil Pastels and Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_title: Have been buying for 30 years...super product.
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I use these semi hard pastels for the first layer in painting to establish underpainting and design. I use super soft pastels over this underpainting.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Sakura Cray-Pas Specialist Oil Pastels and Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_title: Terrific product! Bring back open stock!
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I am a full time professional artist and I can tell you that Cray-Pas Specialist oil pastels are definitely a top level product. Learn how to use them correctly and they are a wonder to work with. Beautiful color, easy blending, a pleasure to use. I combine them with a couple other quality brands in my art and I get phenomenal results. Specialist is very much on par with any professional brand. I am sad to see that Sakura apparently discontinued the open stock. Please consider bringing it back! At any rate, I will continue to buy the sets to augment my oil pastel collection.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Sakura Cray-Pas Specialist Oil Pastels and Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_title: I would buy this product again
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: These oil pastels have wonderful colors. They are not as soft as Senneliers, but they are very usable and great for someone starting out. The colors and ability to manipulate the color on the paper are way above any student brand, but yet, are very affordable.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Sakura Cray-Pas Specialist Oil Pastels and Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: A good oil pastel for serious beginners or seasoned artists. There are quite a few online instructors who recommend and use these, in addition being well mentioned in oil pastel instruction books, from authors John and Sheila Elliot (Oil pastel for the Serious Beginner), and Kenneth Leslie (Oil Pastel, Materials and Techniques for Today's Artist). Expressionist are creamy, pigmented, and affordable. Singles can be purchased should you run out of a color. Expressionist also works well with most other oil pastel brands, such as Mungyo Gallery and Sennelier.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Sakura Cray-Pas Specialist Oil Pastels and Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: These are very soft oil pastels. For beginners these may not be the best as they require more control. But overall very good quality.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Holbein Academic Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: We apologize for the condition of the set you received, and we'd like to take care of this for you. One of our Customer Care Agents will be in touch via email to see how we can help.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Holbein Academic Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: Great pigmentation colors.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Holbein Academic Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I am always willing to est products that I haven't used in the past. Holbein Academy is one of them. I like the round shape. Little crumbling. Good color. Smooth. Not as soft as those I've used, but not near as hard as some.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Holbein Academic Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I'm a hobbyist, and this is one of the first sets I bought for myself. However, I have given sets as gifts, and tried out some other people's pastels. These are great for beginners, they are easy to work with and great for both blending and details. You have to apply color carefully, though, when blending, otherwise there will be streaks of strong color surrounded by light areas. I definitely recommend these for people who are just starting, and looking for good pastels that are easy to work with.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Holbein Academic Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I am brand new at pastels, so my review might not be worth much. I thought they would be softer, but they'e rather hard and they don't layer very well. Or not very well on Canson paper. Maybe once I'm more experienced or use a different, grittier paper, I'll like them better.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Holbein Academic Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I would certanily put theses colors on my artist table.I like to use oil pastels from different manufacturers. Each one has different " character".Some oil pastels are soft and buttery.Some are harder which is great when you want do some detaling in the Painting.I chose Holbein for rhat reason they are slightly harder then other oil pastels.I have yet to give it a test drive.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Niji Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: Made in California not in Japan or China still good oil crayons

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Niji Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: these are firm enough to stay in one piece with paper still attached after using. the full set color selection is good with a nice lavender, purple, several pink gradation hues, as well as blue. The colors layer well when wanting to add shadow and highlight contrasts using darker hues of the same color family.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Niji Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I've only used them once. They are shinny and do look metallic. The sticks are bigger than usual. I am happy with my purchase, and I would totally buy again.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Niji Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_title: For a beginner, nice set of oil pastel
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I was not sure whether I should buy a oil pastel set or not. However, since the price was quite nice, I was able to do so. I did not want to spend money with a product that I have never used before, but I am quite glad that I did it! I am really like this set.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Niji Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_title: I am very happy with the oil pastels
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I am very happy with the oil pastels

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Niji Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: useful

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Niji Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I had ordered these some time ago and decided to try them the other day. What a surprise! The colors are great and they blend easily with your fingers - I LOVE THAT!

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Niji Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I am an Art teacher and used these oil pastels for my classes. I loved them! They were not only smooth but you can layer the colors extremely well. The only problem with them is that they are soft so if you have a large project you will use half of the sticks. But the color is wonderful.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Sargent Art Artists' Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I had planned on ordering multiples of this product but luckily read some of the reviews befor purchasing and ended uo getting just this one box. They are very hard, do NOT blend well if at all, remind me of cheap crayons. The only saving grace is with a little solvent they make be usable in some odd applications, but not for the first time use of this medium for sure.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Sargent Art Artists' Oil Pastel Sets

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Sargent Art Artists' Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_title: Okay for sketching, very low opacity, maybe okay for kids
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: These are almost Identical to the Pentel Oil pastel, however I would give the Sargent's the edge because they do not have the unpleasant smell the Pentel's have. I would recommend these for children, they are probably an excellent deal for teachers or child care providers. For artists they are okay in sketchbooks but like the Pentels they don't have much opacity and similarly leave a lot of crumbs when blending and added multiple colors. Better than the Pentels but if you want something that is a little better quality for sketchbooks and artwork that isn't as expensive as the Neopastel or Sennelier, go with the Cray-Pas Expressionists. In fact, I'd even recommend the cray-pas junior over these, unless you just want something super cheap for little ones. I gave it two stars instead of one because you can buy a giant pack of over 400 for something like $50 and unlike the Pentels you can buy just packs of white or black and they don't smell like gasoline, I think they're great for kids. #sweepstakes

oil_pastels_reviews.review_title: I was surprised by how well these smudged
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I was surprised by how well these smudged into the watercolor paper I used. I can't remember the exact kind of wc paper I was using, but it was rough enough that it took me quite a while to rub the colors I sparsely applied to fill in the pen-ink drawn lines of my rooster drawing. I haven't gone back to finish the drawing, but I am pleased with what I managed to do using only my fingers to smudge and blend.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Cretacolor AquaStic Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_title: works great as a watercolor-oil pastel h
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I use these as a watermedia tool in paintings on their own, or dry on metal or wood. They provide excellent color vibrancy, much better than the "gelatos" and gel sticks that are popular right now--these stay vibrant when wet and don't need a gesso underpainting like the gelatos to get the same result. They also come in a great range of metallics, which I just got, and I am excited about using them! They lift easier and go down more opaque than my traditional watercolors or inks, and while this is a minus if I used them with the paints, it is a great way to get other effects when I use them on their own, especially granular textured effects. I am not a mixed media artist--what I look for as a watercolorist is pigment vibrancy and quality as well as lightfastness, and these provide all that. This was the first media outside of traditonal watercolor paints or inks that I have tried to use seriously, and they produced very exciting results.

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Talens Panda Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: These oil pastels are more waxy than oily and better than most 'student' grade pastels and crayons I've tried. They lay down smooth and blend well. Being a student grade product, the pigmentation is not amazing but the colors are vibrant enough. I love these for sketching out ideas and playing around in my mixed media journals! For the price they are worth a try! Also smooth enough for kids to use without getting frustrated, a big plus!

oil_pastels_reviews.product: Maped Color'Peps Triangular Oil Pastel Sets
oil_pastels_reviews.review_title: I really enjoy these "Kids" oil pastels
oil_pastels_reviews.review_desc: When I first became interested in using oil pastels in my art work, a friend suggested I begin with a budget friendly brand likely marketed for children. It sounded like a good idea so I could get a sense of using them but toss them out if I hated them without being out too much money. I chose the Maped brand on Blick and when it arrived, boy was I pleased! I have since tried other budget friendly brands like Faber Castell and Mungyo but I just love my Maped brand. It has a smooth application with little hand pressure. The coverage is better than many brands in it's price range that I've tried. I like to blend 2 colors usually and that always guarantees complete coverage but just one application of the Maped covers just as well. I use Turpenoid to blend out larger areas and only my finger for smaller areas. Honestly, for just fooling around doing a first sketch these are amazing. Obviously not lightfast, just practical before doing a permanent piece. These are smooth, not grainy, good coverage, nice pigment, tapered ends, all the color choices you need with 24 sticks, and very reasonably priced. Recommended for casual sketching and doodling or outdoor first sketch impressions.

pastel_pencils_reviews.review_desc: I like how the pencils have little slots in little drawers that fit into this textbook-sized case, which is well-built and attractive and protects the pencils from breaking during travel. I'm glad I bought this set since the pastels are hard enough to create details but soft enough to blend with my pastel paintings.

pastel_pencils_reviews.product: Bruynzeel Design Pastel Pencils and Sets
pastel_pencils_reviews.review_title: As a pastel artist, these are incredible pencils.
pastel_pencils_reviews.review_desc: As a professional pastel artist, I have most every brand of pastel available. These are incredible pencils, they're like a secret gem. They're soft bodied and heavily pigmented (no dull, chalky ashy colors). My only wish is that they had a larger set of colors available. I would LOVE more deep dark jewel colors (reds, blues, purples, and greens). I grab for these pencils as often as my Caran D'ache. The pigment shafts are 4mm thick, on par with Derwent, Pitt, and CarbOthello; for the record Caran D'ache is 5mm. Incredible value, I highly, highly recommend these to anyone adding or beginning their pastel collection.

soft_pastels_reviews.product: Townsend Terrages Pastels and Sets
soft_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I am a pastel painter, and I prepare my own rigid surfaces using hardboard or wood panels. These panels may have an aggressive tooth when ready for the studio, My favorite pastels used to block in my background or underpainting are Townsend Terrages due to the fact that they seem to have a fine pumice property that suits my gessoed surface beautifully. The Townsend Terrages pastels grip and adhere to my surface's gritty texture and fills every square millimeter with beautiful pastel color. The adjacent colors I apply are easily blended for soft edges when the picture needs them. The large rectangular shape of Townsend Terrages allows for quick coverage of area without hard telltale streaks on the surface. The Townsend Terrages Manganese Violet 42 is an ideal pastel choice to manage the red violet hint of the atmosphere where the landscape or seascape meets the horizon. This particular tint really approximates the distant haze effect and pushes a pastel's horizon line deep into the perspective. I am happy I found this particular Townsend Terrages color as well many other wonderful pastels Townsend offers. The selection of "darks" is also an important part of my pastel palette.
