They are also packaged oddly in these little plastic individual containers that you need to cut open to get at and because they have room to move around in the containers, they seem to break easily. I ordered 9 individual colors and 3 of them were broken. Blick replaced them, but one of the replacements also arrived broken even though they did a superb job of packing them in bubble wrap the second time. I won't be buying these again. I'll stick with Terry Ludwig or Sennelier soft pastels.

soft_pastels_reviews.product: Holbein Artists' Soft Pastels and Sets
soft_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I like the Holbein Pastels. They seem to be a bit softer than Rembrandts, but the color selection is nicer and they have names that I can relate to, being a former watercolorist. I like the plastic package that each pastel comes in. I keep them in the individual plastic container so that when they break or wear down, I know the color from the label on the plastic container. I would buy these again.

soft_pastels_reviews.product: Holbein Artists' Soft Pastels and Sets
soft_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I really am pleased with this choice. They are beautiful packed, labled and the colors are really bright with a very large selection.

soft_pastels_reviews.product: Richeson Handmade Soft Pastels and Sets
soft_pastels_reviews.review_title: I would buy this product again!
soft_pastels_reviews.review_desc: Such a fun medium. Only purchased one so that I could try it out but now I want more. The pigment and texture are so smooth.

soft_pastels_reviews.product: Richeson Handmade Soft Pastels and Sets
soft_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I am a beginner, taking classes from a great teacher at the university's continuing education program. I use these for the pop of color over the NuPastels. I really love them. They really are rich , easy to use and help with colors I don't have. This is a nice assortment of 24.

soft_pastels_reviews.product: Richeson Handmade Soft Pastels and Sets

soft_pastels_reviews.product: Richeson Handmade Soft Pastels and Sets
soft_pastels_reviews.review_desc: Richeson comes in several hardness/softness. These are just right. They are smoothe and easy to work with because of the large size of the stick. On a scale of hard to soft, 1-10 I would give these an 8 for softness

soft_pastels_reviews.product: Richeson Handmade Soft Pastels and Sets
soft_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I sampled many of the top-rated pastels available and found these to be the softest, smoothest, and most vibrant. They have a creamy texture and blend beautifully.

soft_pastels_reviews.product: Richeson Half-Stick Medium-Soft Pastel Sets
soft_pastels_reviews.review_title: Intense, bold color; great for accents, defined lines
soft_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I decided to try a set of Richeson's after reading they are good for lines and detail. I use primarily softer brands- Great American, Terry Ludwig. I was not dissappointed eith these pastels. They are soft, but draw a uniform and (if desired) defined line or other accent marks. The remind me of Unison in firmness, perhaps a little harder. Richeson offers so many bold, attractive colors. I have been considering giving them a try for some time, and since the price is reasonable- so I am sure I'll order another set in the future.

soft_pastels_reviews.product: Richeson Half-Stick Medium-Soft Pastel Sets
soft_pastels_reviews.review_desc: Exactly what I wanted and ordered! The pastel pencils and pan pastels were well packaged and got here safely.

soft_pastels_reviews.product: Richeson Half-Stick Medium-Soft Pastel Sets
soft_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I bought these to go into the Richeson pastel carrier for Plein Air. They have worked well and the colors are amazing.

soft_pastels_reviews.product: Richeson Half-Stick Medium-Soft Pastel Sets
soft_pastels_reviews.review_title: Very happy with this pastel set
soft_pastels_reviews.review_desc: Very happy with this pastel set! I'd say they're a medium softness. The colors go on the paper nicely without having to use to much pressure , so they should last me awhile. They also go over top of one another great, allowing for good amounts of layering. So I'm very pleased :)

soft_pastels_reviews.product: Richeson Half-Stick Medium-Soft Pastel Sets
soft_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I got this set to use mainly for underpaintings, as they are a medium hard pastel, and not to be confused with the Richeson handrolled pastels. The pastels have nice, rich pigments, so I will get good use out of them. This would be a great set for beginners who are looking to establish a palette for a reasonable price

soft_pastels_reviews.product: Richeson Half-Stick Medium-Soft Pastel Sets
soft_pastels_reviews.review_title: This set of pastels is great for first stage pastel work
soft_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I use these pastels as my layer after the pan pastels. They are a medium softness. I use something softer, like Sennelier, as my final touch.

soft_pastels_reviews.product: Richeson Half-Stick Medium-Soft Pastel Sets
soft_pastels_reviews.review_desc: These pastels are the perfect mix of hard vs soft pastel. They are hard enough to make a pinpoint mark, make a light layer, yet soft enough to lay down rich pigment. Bravo!

soft_pastels_reviews.product: Art Spectrum Artists' Soft Pastels and Sets

soft_pastels_reviews.product: Art Spectrum Artists' Soft Pastels and Sets
soft_pastels_reviews.review_desc: This, together with Warm White P and Yellow Ochre X make a very useful trio of pale warm neutral colors. Art Spectrum Soft neutrals are not dull and will not deaden areas of a pastel painting. These medium soft slightly gritty sticks give back a little tooth as they're applied, making it easy to layer colors over each other.

soft_pastels_reviews.product: Art Spectrum Artists' Soft Pastels and Sets
soft_pastels_reviews.review_desc: This really is a smoldering dark! Not only that, the Flinders Violets, both red and blue, are simply beatiful. I am, though, avoiding the blue violet very tinted (V) and extra tinted (X), because they are not fully lightfast, being rated only two stars, the equivalent of ASTM III (Good).

soft_pastels_reviews.product: Art Spectrum Artists' Soft Pastels and Sets
soft_pastels_reviews.review_title: Beautiful, Useful, But Some Not Lightfast
soft_pastels_reviews.review_desc: On the whole, I could use Art Spectrum Soft Pastels exclusively. The color range may seem limited, but it really does cover what's needed for the general pastel artist who isn't trying to copy a subject. This particular tint of red, however, represents the one weakness: some of the tints have a lightfast rating of "good," the equivalent of ASTMIII or Blue Wool Scale 4-5. Spectrum Red, Yellow Green, Flinder's Blue Violet, Spectrum Yellow, Jacaranda, Spectrum Orange being among them. If you're using these professionally I'd recommend downloading the color chart (found via the Resources tab) on Art Spectrum's website.

soft_pastels_reviews.product: Art Spectrum Artists' Soft Pastels and Sets
soft_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I "tested the water" by trying the box of 40 half sticks, a good place to start. These pastels are medium soft with a little grit that gives back some tooth as they're applied to the paper. I'm finally able to achieve the layering effect I couldn't get with softer pastels. Most of the colors (whole range) are rated either excellent or very good, but if lightfastness is important to you, go to Art Spectrum's website, open the Resources tab, and download the color chart for these Soft Pastels. Any that are marked with two stars are rated good, which is not lightfast enough for professional use.

soft_pastels_reviews.product: Art Spectrum Artists' Soft Pastels and Sets
soft_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I like Art Spectrum Artists soft pastels because I find the texture a delight to work with. On sanded paper, the texture works well for painting clouds and of course anything else. I can get some good details with this brand.

soft_pastels_reviews.product: Art Spectrum Artists' Soft Pastels and Sets

Great for small hands, organization, keeping them stored and separated and clean up IN A CLASSROOM. I have used soft pastels for a long time professionally and this is a great economical beginner quality for young artists! WILL BUY AGAIN!

soft_pastels_reviews.product: Blockx Soft Pastels and Sets
soft_pastels_reviews.review_desc: First time seeing what Blockx soft pastel's are all about. They are a little larger than I had hoped. I was looking for a pastel for grasses, but the colors and smoothness are really nice. Can't wait to experiment with it on m landscapes.

soft_pastels_reviews.product: Blockx Soft Pastels and Sets
soft_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I purchased this as an alternative to, or addition to, the hard pastels that I normally use, specifically to work more on black/dark paper. This is, as expected, more messy than the hard pastels I usually use. This became immediately evident when I opened the shipping box and found the inside of the box completely coated in white pastel, with some making its way between the bottom flaps. Fortunately, I knew that this box contained soft pastels, and I was (somewhat) prepared for the transfer of white to every single thing between the door and what would be the (now multiplied in number) soft pastels' eventual home. Dick Blick has since proven that they are able to successfully contain these pastels through the shipping process, so hopefully everyone will now receive theirs intact and with less need of a shower. These are satisfactorily soft pastels, and the titanium white is bright. Wear an apron, and keep your shop rags handy.

soft_pastels_reviews.product: Blockx Soft Pastels and Sets
soft_pastels_reviews.review_title: Blockx is my go to brand from now on.
soft_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I received these quickly and the price is great. Blockx pastels are the most underrated pastels out there. I never see them in reviews on the different blogs that I look at. The colors are great and they are a good choice between extremely soft, but expensive, Schminkes, for example and Rembrandts. I can't say enough about the colors: They are fantastic. The price per stick is very reasonable as well. More pastelists should look at these as a serious alternative for all genres of work.

soft_pastels_reviews.product: Blockx Soft Pastels and Sets
soft_pastels_reviews.review_desc: About the same hardness as Rembrandts. A good pastel to use on laying down first layers. The size is good for the price. #sweepstakes

soft_pastels_reviews.review_title: AP Non-Toxic, Tin, Artist grade Pigment, Lightfast
soft_pastels_reviews.review_desc: I bought the 30 set to use as a travel and art class set. The sturdy storage tin along with AP Non-Toxic, artist grade pigment and lightfast pastels were very important. The color palette is the same in the new W&N oil pastel set for those who like to use oil pastels as their pastel underpainting. Attached test drawing of spheres is on vellum cardstock. Pros: Pigmented, soft, finger blendable, good color range in the 30 set. Soft color shapers also work as blenders. Cons: No open stock. A 15 set might be an option to refill commonly used colors in the 30 set as needed. Made in China. Hopefully, W&N supervises the Chinese manufacturing to ensure quality and non-toxic products.

acrylics_reviews.product: Golden Open Acrylic Paints and Sets
acrylics_reviews.review_title: Open Up Your Options with Golden Open Acrylics
acrylics_reviews.review_desc: Golden Open Acrylics changed the game for acrylic painters. You can mix large amounts of paint and have a palette that stays workable for days, avoiding wasted paint and time remixing. Colors blend on the substrate like oils for beautiful soft edges. I use Open titanium white for tinting regular heavy-body paint, which lets me control the drying time, leveraging the advantage of using fast-drying acrylic paint. Using an Open medium helps control the drying time for darker colors. You will have to take care when using water. Water may reactivate touch-dry Open paint on your substrate and you could end up pulling it right off, even with a brush loaded with paint. But with practice, you'll find the limits of what works and doesn't work. The bottom line is, your options will be more Open with Golden Open acrylics. The widemouth 8 oz jar makes it easy to use every bit of paint. Putting some plastic wrap over the top before closing the jar makes it easy to open every time. I'd give Open paints a 5-star review anyway. It's just gravy to do it for #sweepstakes

acrylics_reviews.product: Golden High Flow Acrylic Paints and Sets
acrylics_reviews.review_title: Too weak, no tinting strength when mixed with other paints
acrylics_reviews.review_desc: This was the first High Flow paint I've gotten that is in their "Transparent" line. I really should have believed Blick's provided swatch. This is an incredibly weak yellow oxide. I made the mistake of thinking it was what is usually called Transparent yellow iron oxide, which is a less opaque alternative to yellow oxide or ochre. In this case, it's so poorly pigmented to the point of acting like dirty high flow medium when mixed with other brands' acrylic inks or with other Golden High Flow paints. If used alone it's a passably decent transparent wash of earthy yellow. But overall, not really in line with what I expect from Golden paints. #sweepstakes

acrylics_reviews.product: Chroma Acrylic Mural Paint and Sets
acrylics_reviews.review_title: LOVE the paint, HATE the containers...
acrylics_reviews.review_desc: We use this paint in a Community Arts class for interior and exterior murals, and in general art classes for projects. The coverage is phenomenal, it blends really well, and the colors are vibrant. The only negative point is the containers they come in. There isn't an easy way to pour paint out for distribution, and what ultimately happens is that paint crusts up around the lip of the jar, the lid eventually won't go on correctly, and the paint dries out with only half of it used. Almost every jar has done this-- either it dries out completely, or it's just a thick, gelatinous mess by the time you get about half of it used. I wish they would come up with a better lid/container solution because this paint is such an affordable alternative.

acrylics_reviews.product: Chroma Acrylic Mural Paint and Sets
acrylics_reviews.review_desc: I painted my first mural and couldn't be happier!! This paint covers very well, not need to multiple application. It also blends very well both on palette and on "canvas". The color names are unique but I found it very easy to get the colors I needed or could mix to make work for my design. Excited to begin my second mural once weather allows as it will be outside. #blicksweepstakes

acrylics_reviews.review_desc: Let me suggest enlarging the type indicating the color on your paint tubes. I have a tube of Liquitex metallic paint (.74 fl.oz) on which the color description on the front is set in type so small as to be nearly unreadable. Look at the tube and notice how much empty space there is that could hold a bolder type. Whoever laid this out must return to art school for some advertising classes. Don't forget, many older artists have enough trouble finding their glasses much less reading such minuscule type. Why not make it easier to read?

acrylics_reviews.product: Chromacryl Acrylic Essentials Paints and Sets
acrylics_reviews.review_title: Best Paint for High School Art Class.
acrylics_reviews.review_desc: I purchased this paint in 1/2 gallon primary colors set of six. The paint made it through 6 years of teaching without separating, or drying out. The colors were rich, and my students were able to blend them to create other colors without making mud. We used them for paintings and paint pouring. I purchased another brand in a few colors and within two years they were separated and drying. I had no problems with the Chroma brand. I also purchased the pumps, which I do not recommend for long term storage. It was easier for my students to get a reasonable amount, but I needed to do an extensive clean out each spring or fall to use the pumps again. The colors I ran out of, I repurchased in the pint size for ease of pouring. I saw these paints, without pumps, at a workshop I attended at a local university, which is why I tried them initially.

acrylic_paintbrushes_reviews.review_title: A Useful Brush that I Use Often
acrylic_paintbrushes_reviews.review_desc: The Princeton Snap filbert brush is one that I use often to push paint around and scrub paint. It's an excellent brush for dry brush blending and layering of paint. It's like an old hog bristle brush in the sense that the bristles become splayed under often and heavy use, and it remains very useful even when it's heavily worn. I have two of these brushes in sizes 8 and 12 filbert.

acrylic_paintbrushes_reviews.product: Princeton SNAP! Series 9650 Golden Synthetic Brushes and Sets
acrylic_paintbrushes_reviews.review_desc: Best in the business!

acrylic_paintbrushes_reviews.product: Princeton SNAP! Series 9650 Golden Synthetic Brushes and Sets
acrylic_paintbrushes_reviews.review_desc: This Princeton Snap! Golden Taklon brush is a great brush for smallish paintings or for specific areas of a larger canvas. I love the short handle (not sure why I used the longer handled brushes in the past) and have several other Princeton short handled brushes that I use all the time. I like my hand/brush being closer to the surface that I'm painting on instead of farther away. Being closer feels more like I'm drawing and painting at the same time.

erasers_reviews.review_title: Thinner, flimsier imitation of the Staedtler shield
erasers_reviews.review_desc: I bought this shield to do precise erasing of botanical drawings. Because other reviewers complained about this shield being flimsy, and others talked up the Staedtler, I decided to buy both so that I could compare them. And they are different. This shield is about a centimeter longer than the Staedtler and the holes are a little larger, though they almost copy the original shapes. These holes are more rounded and not as narrow as the competitor's shield. I agree with others that the Westcott feels thinner and less robust. So I measured thickness with a micrometer. Yes, I actually did. The Westcott measures a pretty reproducible 0.09 mm in multiple places around its perimeter. The Staedtler, however, measures 0.12 mm. Again, I made multiple measurements around the perimeter of each and the Westcott is about 25% thinner. You really can feel the difference. In the end, though, they both function as an erasing shield just fine. But I don't think that the Westcott will prove to be as durable. It already has a divot (see photo). One of these will stay in my home; one will travel with my kit. Either way, they need a wallet or sleeve. The Staedtler will just fit in a wallet. The thinner Westcott is too big. It was interesting to compare these two, but I would probably buy two Staedtlers instead of one of each.

erasers_reviews.review_title: A Vast Improvement Over the Original Eraser
erasers_reviews.review_desc: For those of my colleagues who are old enough to fondly remember the original Eberhard Faber Blackwing 602, it did have one notable Achilles Heel: its pink rubber eraser. Stiff when new, it became leather hard and crumbly when old. Yes, the pencil's ferule was designed to allow the user to exchange a new one, but to what avail? Your options were limited to those pink erasers. Today, the legendary Blackwing 602 has been resurrected with an eraser to match the quality of its smooth lead and aromatic cedar casing - a rarity in the pencil world. While this new incarnation of the 602 is a close match to the original, it's new pink replacement eraser is not - and that is a good thing! It is far superior to it. #sweepstakes

The small particles coming out of the pad fall onto the surface and absorb (bond to) any loose powder, dust, or dirt that is then able to be swept off by the pad which, unlike your hand, will leave the surface clean and smudge-free. Please note that a Cleaning Pad is not an eraser, it will not remove drawn marks or embedded smudges. erasers_reviews.review_title: The better of the two available erasing shields
erasers_reviews.review_desc: This review is the counterpart to the review that I wrote about the inferior competitor to the Staedtler trading shield. I bought this shield (the Staedtler) to do precise erasing of botanical drawings. Because other reviewers complained about the Westcott shield being flimsy, and others talked up the Staedtler, I decided to buy both so that I could compare them. And they are different. This shield is about a centimeter shorter than the Westcott. This is not an issue and actually makes it a bit more portable. I agree with other reviewers that the Staedtler feels more sturdy. So I measured thickness with a micrometer. Yes, I actually did. The Westcott measures a pretty reproducible 0.09 mm in multiple places around its perimeter. The Staedtler, however, measures 0.12 mm. Again, I made multiple measurements around the perimeter of each and the Westcott is about 25% thinner. You really can feel the difference. They both function as an erasing shield just fine, however. In the end I think that this one, the Staedtler, will be more durable. The substantially thinner Westcott already has a divot (see photo). One of these will stay in my home; one will travel with my kit. Either way, they need a wallet or sleeve. The Staedtler will just fit in a wallet. The thinner Westcott is too big. It was interesting to compare these two, but I would probably buy two Staedtlers instead of one of each

erasers_reviews.review_title: One of the best erasers ever for sketchers
erasers_reviews.review_desc: If you're like me, you're in search of an eraser that can erase lead, (carbon, pencil, etc.) and truly erase. I've found three erasers so far, and this is one. Just remember not to draw so dark it etches the lines into your paper, and this little dude will work for you. (Blick's own erasers work, Tombow pencil 2.3 round, and the Factis or Factus soap also are amazing for sketchers). Blick's prices can't be beat, so try this, then try them all, until you find the one you love. I love this one, and it's a regular for me. It's smooth, soft, and picks up my mistakes easily.

I love using this eraser as a general clean-up tool, and to remove a large swath of graphite if need be. Smooth and softly textured, this eraser can get through multiple layers of varying lead hardnesses with ease. It leaves you with a nice, clean area to go in and redo if you've made a mistake. I also really like how it doesn't smear the graphite all over your work. You can use these erasers with a variety of brands; (woodless or wooded,) and even graphite chunks. They do an outstanding job of cleaning up and you go and after you've finished. If there was a version with sharp edges; I would buy it in a heartbeat.

I use this for cleaning the hard covers of old books. It works pretty much like an eraser. You do have to have realistic expectations as it works great on surface dirt. For old ground-in dirt, it will make it look better but it won't completely remove it. It's also perfect for lampshades, that just get really dusty. All in all, I'm happy with my purchase.

learned about this product in a workshop recent. we used it for getting unwanted ink marks off damp intaglio printed paper - excellent cleanup without tearing paper. Everyone in our class have ordered this because it's so good.

I use the cleaning pad for herbarium specimens that are often quite old (100 years). It removes the accumulated dust,grime, and oils from hands without damaging the old paper. I have used it for a long time and finally wore a hole in the seam at the top of the bag. I just put a rubber band around the top and was good-to-go.

Also, I'm not a huge fan of disposable cartridges, and I wish there was a version I could refill, maybe with different ink.

calligraphy_reviews.review_title: Pilot Parallel - Budget-friendly Fountain Pens for Artists
calligraphy_reviews.review_desc: I discovered the Pilot Parallel pens after reading they are a preferred tool used by the likes of Ashley Wood. I see how they can be used to create that organic, thick, thin, spontaneous line quality he excels at. Not as impressed with the ink that comes in the package, but the pen works with a Con-40 converter that I filled with waterproof Rohrer and Klingner Sketch Ink in the Lotte Black. I'm very impressed with the effortless variable line quality and deep and rich blacks (also recommend that ink). So now I have a goto fountain pen for inking my cartoon art. Viva Lost Cactus! By the way, these pens must be in high demand because of limited availability here and on other sites.

calligraphy_reviews.review_title: Great pen and size. Sharp lines
calligraphy_reviews.review_desc: I love the pilot parallel pens. This pen is found cheaper in the store but it's only in stock online so I got it online. I have multiple pens. 1 in each size. Multiple in some sizes because the inner barrel plastic breaks where the threading is. Usually happens after several years though so they are worth it. This size specifically 4.5 is a nice size, smaller than the 6 which uses a lot of ink.

calligraphy_reviews.review_title: Great pens for small calligraphic lettering
calligraphy_reviews.review_desc: I found these Speedball calligraphy fountain pens after working with the Pilot Parallel pens for some time. The Pilot Parallels are great for calligraphy, but the smallest size nib they offer is 1.5mm, and the ink flows quite freely from them, making it difficult to produce smaller calligraphic letters. The Speedball pen nibs come in 1.1mm, 1.5mm, and 1.9mm and I've found that the ink flow is less heavy than the Pilot Parallel pens, so it's easier to produce those tiny letters, while still retaining the line variation necessary for great looking calligraphy. The pen body itself is nothing fancy, just sturdy plastic. It also features a small window so you can see when you're running low on ink. The cap is secure, and posts on the back of the pen nicely while writing or drawing. The only thing I don't love about these pens is that the interior of the pen body is made to only fit the short standard international fountain pen cartridges. There are little plastic bumps inside the pen body shaft which prevent any longer cartridges from fitting. These bumps actually hold the cartridge in place inside the pen when it's assembled, so be careful when disassembling the pen because the cartridge might fall out from the nib and spill ink. It would be nice to be able to fit a longer cartridge in there, but it's easy enough to change to a new cartridge, or refill the old one from an ink bottle with a flat syringe. Overall, these pens are a quality and completely affordable writing or drawing instrument.

calligraphy_reviews.review_desc: I have not opened my new package of these but have used these in the past. These Maru nibs allow for extremely thin lines. although these nibs are designed for thin lines, they also are flexible enough for a fairly thick line. Some art supplies stores sell cheap pen holders for these round nibs which have a skinny handle. those cheap pen holders cause my hand to cramp up. The Kuretake Zig (Tachikawa) pen holder does not cramp my hand yet fits the round maru nib as well as the Saji, G, and School nibs. I believe many Shojo type manga artists use this nib for details such as hair. Because hair strands are so numerous this nib seems to dull faster than my other nibs. I think it is odd they only include 2 instead of 3 or more nibs in the package, still this is a very good nib. This nib allows for lines comparable to the finest Micron pens, but without the worries of breaking the tip. I would buy this in combination with either the G nib or School nib for figure drawing. The Saji is supposed to be used for backgrounds but can also produce figures.

I recently bought this Manuscript set. I'm a newish calligrapher. I decided I wanted to use the refillable cartridge and filled it with Higgins India Ink for fountain pens. It worked sort of ok for the smallest nib but not at all for the larger ones. I decided maybe the ink, which was opened and seemed ok to me, might be too thick for the pen. I removed the refillable cartridge and put on a standard black cartridge and voila! A different outcome altogether. Much smoother with no skipping using all nib sizes. So if you have trouble be sure to consider the ink you're using. And if you are not a seasoned calligrapher, remember to be sure you are holding the pen the way it is made to be held. Note that buying two of a one-pack is cheaper than buying a two-pack...typical fine art prices, but Blick makes it affordable.

Note: always rinse and completely dry the nips after each use so the ink doesn't dry on the nib, sealing it, and the water doesn't corrode the metal nibs over time, making the nibs useless.

That said; I find myself using both books to accomplish meet my rudimentary needs. There are a few good pointers in Speedball's book that are useful. If I had to do it all over again, I might have bough each separately as I can only learn one handle and nib at a time.
This is great for calligraphy I prefer thicker nibs for writing, but you get a lot for the money. so it is great

I purchased this as a gift for someone who wanted to try out calligraphy but wasn't sure where to start. The pieces in the set aren't what they will be using for long, but they wouldn't have known that without giving them a try. This set is a great low price for that initial calligraphy craving.

My first impression was I just bought something that is heirloom quality. The box has a solid feel, is pleasing to the eyes and the pieces fit solidly. I love the variety of nibs and holders as I can use them for both calligraphy and ink drawings. I was less imressed with the ink containers as there are no seals in the lids and I can see ink seeping out and making a huge mess. Rather than include a just few colors of ink, I'd have gladly bought my own if there was a complete set of nibs. All in all, I'm glad I spent the extra money for this set. There's something spiritual about using fine writing instruments.

calligraphy_reviews.review_title: I use as a unique drawing tool.
calligraphy_reviews.review_desc: This seems to be a capable calligraphy tool Unfortunately; I don't do calligraphy. I introduce this to my drawing students as it has a a curious quality. When you wet the ink while the ink is still wet, it separates into magenta (pink) and cyan (turquois) colors. The cyan is most visible but if you blot the ink, some of the cyan comes off leaving the magenta. I wet the ink with an inexpensive brush. The ink does dry permanently so do keep your brush wet when using. Consider cleaning brush with soap and water.

I'm still trying figure out how to use these with watercolor. They make a dark bold line that doesn't soften with water the way I imagined, so I need to figure out what subjects it makes sense to use them with.

calligraphy_reviews.review_title: long lasting, beautiful pigments, durable tips
calligraphy_reviews.review_desc: These languished unused in a basement for 15 years and still work. The colors are clear, bold, bright but not "childish" or super high-chroma. Layering the purple and and greens makes a magnetic deep dark value. They adopt the sheen of the surface you draw on. If your paper is matte, they dry to a clean flat matte. If your paper has a very smooth finish, they develop a subtle sheen. The black is truly black. Even under direct sunlight I cannot detect any add-mixtures of pigments. The tips are consistently square with gentle precise rounding at the corners. That tends to make normal handwriting seem special, and good handwriting seem like Art. Acid free, archival "safe." Fun to write with. Even more fun to sketch with! I'll definitely invest in more!

I use this marker in my business— whenever I write thank you notes for a customer order, I use this pen to write the recipient's name on the envelope containing the note and receipt. I've bought several colors but the one I use most is Aquamarine.
I love the smooth lettering I can achieve with these markers. The ink doesn't skip. The markers are easy to control.
I had a calligraphy project in mind but my pens were dried out. I ordered these pens and I am very happy with the quality of the pens. My project came out beautiful!

Very vibrant! I bought the red and wine color. These are so pretty and write very nice. Very sensitive markers where writing on legal pad for practice is too rough for it. It does a lot better on Rhodia paper

This is a beautiful marker. I am using them to ink mylar for screenprinting. I also use the other Sakura paint pens but the nib on these pens gives me better control for my drawing style. The ink is very opaque so I don't have to worry about light passing through when either exposing or scanning.
Using to add accents to already printed etchings and engravings.

I love the quality of gold paint these pens have. It's by far my favorite metallic paint color. However they're action can be a bit funky so it's best to get the paint following on a scrap paper first. Also by the gods make sure store these correctly.

They can clog up or become too saturated and throw off the lines that were created when you started. I would recommend to use the pen to it's end once you start if possible to ensure consistent flow and lines.

calligraphy_reviews.review_title: Good Flow, Rich Solid Black Ink, Non-bleeding
calligraphy_reviews.review_desc: I have had a hard time finding a calligraphy marker as perfect as the Staedtler Calligraph Duo, which is no longer available for single, black marker purchases (only assorted color sets). For years, I was spoiled by that marker's excellent ink flow, rich black color, non-bleeding character, sharp edges, and desired tip widths. However, after trying many alternatives, the Yasutumo meets most of those performance needs for me. I just have to work a bit harder to keep a sharp edge. I use the 2mm and 3.5mm for calligraphy, which were the two sizes on the Staedtler Duo, so I am happy Yasutumo offers them in the same set.

These calligraphy markers are the best of the four different types I purchased. They are the easiest for a beginner to use and get a result that actually looks like calligraphy! I will definitely purchase these again.

calligraphy_reviews.review_title: A great product for a specific purpose

I love the color separation of light purples and pinks. Its comparable to Elegant Writer except Elegant Writer does not set as well.

I use the 2.0 pen the most for my calligraphy business. I like this way better than actual ink because it doesn't bleed through paper or spread in the pores in the paper. I use the 3.5 and 5.0 with my students for posters. They love using them. The only complaint is that they are markers so they run out kind of quickly especially with the children but the price is so reasonable that it doesn't matter that you have to buy a lot.
Love them for drawings and greeting cards. The ink flow is just wonderful across the paper. Just ordered all the colors available.

Bought the Dark Green in Broad Point, the Red Broad Point and the Metallic Green Medium. As you can see from my images (not my best lettering): - the Dark Green is pretty decent, as it's a true green and I was able to get nice crisp sharp lines. - The Red however, for some reason, didn't have sharp edges AND in-person, it looks more orange-red than a true red (however, from my photo, it looks red). Trust me... I'm picky with my reds and this is more of an orange red. - The Metallic Green is fairly decent. Again, edges not as crisp as the other green (maybe they sent me 2 bum/used pens?) and as you can see on the black paper, it shows up as a silver-ish green. Bottom line, I probably would not purchase again. Am looking for red & green chisel markers for Cmas (med to broad point) -- like the Elegant Writers. Maybe I'll try to "sharpen" these myself with my xacto knife. Even then, though, I'm disappointed with the red color. Decent price though!

I like this paper, & use it in my calligraphy workshops; however, I get mixed reviews from folks learning calligraphy for the first time mentioning the subtle, horizontal ridges in the paper can assist in "snags" when creating upstrokes. It's a great paper other than that! Not 100% smooth, but still nice quality.

calligraphy_reviews.review_title: Not bad, but I prefer 400 series smooth drawing pad...
calligraphy_reviews.review_desc: I've come to prefer and love the 400 series SMOOTH drawing pad for my work (the one with the lion head on the cover) due to the fact that I do super flexible pointed pen work. The woven finish (similar to laid finish on stationery) on these 400 series Calligraphy pads are generally too textured for me and my flexible tines (it's just my preference). Yes, the drawing pads are more expensive and ivory color and only 24 sheets to a pad but it is beautiful fine, smooth paper and heavy enough for finish work. I splurge and buy a 1/2 dozen every year. Buying by the dozen is even cheaper at Blick. I highly recommend it. Try a pad and see for yourself.

calligraphy_reviews.review_title: I have purchased this lovely metallic gold four times!
calligraphy_reviews.review_desc: I have fallen in love with the gorgeousness of this metallic gold ink. I work in mixed media so I experiment a lot, so far my favorite use is over black India ink and texture.

Let me start by saying these are quality inks. I thought they would be more opaque but here's my approach: 1: opacity- added Holbein gouache of similar tones to my inks. I still have to paint my colors twice on watercolor paper for full opacity. But this makes your inks more powerful than Holbeins acrylic gouache and In desired consistency. This will make your inks stronger than most available for purchase. Holbein I hope you're listening. We need more opaque colors that aren't pastel. This is a sure thing. 2: tip dry nib or airbrush- make a mix of glycerine/propylene glycol to make an acrylic retarder. I used vape juice bottles so I can add drops to however much I'm using at the time. This is the only way I was able to outline black with a nib. I add about 7-8 drops in a small cap and go to town. These are just things that have helped me out over the last few months. These aren't things that are necessary by any means. Just sharing some tricks that have made these my favorite new paints. I'm only leaving four stars because I feel like this ink has potential to be the absolute best if they added their gouache to it. Even to just make an extension off of this product. Then we'd have the opaque and transparent sets, that way you're making everyone happy. I also wish I could purchase bigger bottles. Overall Holbein has my business! The Japanese make amazing art supplies and I'm very happy that dick blick carries these products for all of us to try and use.

The Speedball Calligraphy Ink in Emerald Green is absolutely stunning! The vibrant, jewel-toned green adds a fresh and elegant touch to any project. Its smooth, consistent flow ensures clean, crisp lines, making it a dream for both calligraphy and detailed illustrations. The rich color stands out beautifully on paper and dries to a perfect finish. This ink brings a lively, luxurious feel.

The Speedball Calligraphy Ink in Scarlet Red is exceptional! The 2 oz bottle provides a rich, vibrant red that flows smoothly and consistently, perfect for creating striking calligraphy or detailed artwork. The ink dries quickly with a beautiful sheen, ideal for professional and hobbyist projects. The bold yet elegant color adds a distinctive pop to any piece. Whether you're working on invitations, letters, or artistic designs, this ink delivers top-notch quality and precision. It is highly recommended for anyone seeking a reliable and eye-catching ink!

Speedball's Calligraphy Ink in Primrose Yellow is a bright and cheerful addition to any artist or calligrapher's collection. The 2 oz bottle holds a generous amount of ink, and its vibrant yellow color stands out for its striking opacity and smooth flow. This makes it perfect for everything from calligraphy and lettering to illustrations and fine art projects. One of the key highlights of this ink is its fluidity. It glides effortlessly on various surfaces, from traditional calligraphy paper to heavier mixed media paper, offering consistent, clean lines without clogging dip pens or brushes. The Primrose Yellow shade is lively, providing a sunny, vivid pop of color that holds its brightness even after drying. It dries to a smooth, satin finish and remains fade-resistant, keeping your artwork fresh and vibrant. The ink's rich pigmentation means that it works well on both light and dark surfaces, and it can also be mixed with other colors from the Speedball range for custom hues. It's highly versatile, making it ideal for calligraphy and adding decorative touches to cards, journals, and more. One minor drawback is that, like many lighter inks, Primrose Yellow may require a couple of layers on darker backgrounds to achieve full opacity. However, its buildable nature makes it easy to control the level of intensity. Overall, Speedball's Calligraphy Ink in Primrose Yellow is a fantastic choice for anyone looking to add vivid, high-quality ink to their creative toolkit. Its brightness, fluidity, and versatility make it a standout option for seasoned calligraphers and beginners.

calligraphy_reviews.review_desc: I use this product for white highlights and cleanup details around marker and ink drawings. The built-in brush tool makes it easy to use and functional, which I like. There will be some separation that occurs, so you have to be sure to mix the ink prior to using - a long toothpick usually works best for this. If not mixed before applying, the ink will dry down with a slight yellow tint to it, and if over darker colors will not be as opaque. One small downside is that the ink easily "beads up" on the applicator during use, especially if you've shaken or even turned the bottle to mix the ink. Even if you wipe the excess off the bristles on the rim of the bottle, you have to keep an eye out for extra product that will bead up higher on the wand. These beads of ink will roll down the applicator and brush pretty quickly as you're using it, if you don't watch out. Overall the product is good, and I will continue to repurchase. #sweepstakes

calligraphy_reviews.review_title: Extra, extra! Artist now happy camper!
calligraphy_reviews.review_desc: I've searched and searched my local art supplies stores for a water-soluble ink. Except for a single, basic black exception, I could not find an ink that was not waterproof. I guess calligraphy makes the waterproof inks more popular, fair enough, but I use my ink, in all colors, in my visual art. I "pull" color from my ink. It's an important and much needed, aspect of my art. After searching around, I found Blick. Not only did they have the product I was after, they also had it at a price much better than I could expect to pay at any retailer. I was so pleased, I purchased much more than I originally intended. Hey, when you see a good deal, you take advantage of it. I think each time I use it, I'm more pleased. Thumbs up Blick!

I love using Higgins ink in all of my illustrations. I won't deny it. Using this ink rather than a watercolor paint gives a certain vibrancy you cannot achieve using another medium. Majority of the colors will say "non-waterproof," but when working with it, you will find that if you find yourself spilling water on a completed piece, majority of the colors act as though they were "waterproof." Out of my experiences with Black India, Russet, Red-Orange, Red, Violet, Blue, "Green", Turquoise, and Leaf-Green... The only colors which have proven themselves to move when re-dampened have been Blue and "Green." On this note, WARNING: INK, especially INDIA INK will NOT come out of clothing! Now, the reason I put "Green" in quotation marks is because "Green" is far closer to a blue hue than any type of green... In fact, I typically use it when painting skies. You have got to be weary when choosing colors, the color you may think you want could end up looking entirely different. Use scrap paper when painting, see what it looks like dried before using it, too. Another thing about using these inks is how they blend. If you're new to the medium, it will shock you: Once the ink has dried on the paper, there is little to no chance of moving it. If you want a gradient, you must add it before it dries. This is both a blessing and a curse. If you let the ink dry before evening out the paint, you are left with a crisp line where the water's edge was, but if you plan on it drying, you are guaranteed layers which will not become muddy the more layers you add. Colors will blend with each other if you mix them while wet or on your palette, but if you allow the paint to dry before you add an extra color the DEPTH you achieve is far greater than if you were to attempt the same thing in any other medium. You can show distinct violets and distinct greens right to each other without becoming too muddy if you desire, you can't get that too easily with other mediums. It may also seem like you're buying a tiny bottle of ink, but just a few drops will go a long way. I started using Ink as my primary medium 6 months ago, and only recently have I started to begin replacing bottles. Higgins ink, like all art mediums alike, takes some getting used to. If you want to achieve high-intensity colors, Higgins ink is a good place to find it. If you are looking for a new challenge, I would highly recommend Higgins Ink. As the inks are mainly permanent and highly concentrated, do not buy for younger artists. Watercolors are great for kids, but if you're looking for something new to try, look into "gouache." Happy Creating!

calligraphy_reviews.review_title: I would buy this product again.
calligraphy_reviews.review_desc: I am using these, as well as the Yasutomo All Purpose Brushes, for Suminagashi. The size of these brushes (handle, overall diameter and belly) are larger than the All Purpose brushes with the same numbering system. This makes it much easier for me to hold multiple brushes in one hand. But the size difference is something to be aware of if you prefer to work with smaller brushes. Hair does fall out. At this price point that is to be expected. The best way to help with shedding is to properly remove starch when they arrive, inspect and then carefully remove the loose hair. Gently swirl the brush in the cup of your hand under cold, running water while cleaning. Lightly wipe on a lint free cloth to remove excess water. Avoid squeezing or pinching to remove water. Shape and hang to dry. Before any session I fan the dry bristles with my fingers to see if there are any loose hairs. I've had very little to no shedding with the 6 brushes I own. I've used them multiple times a day for two weeks. These brushes hold a nice amount of ink and surfactant. They also keep their shape after I've curved the bristles to change the angle of the toe. I would recommend these brushes over the marbling kit brushes. Half of those have lost many bristles even after gentle care.

calligraphy_reviews.review_title: I will not buy this product again
calligraphy_reviews.review_desc: Thank you for taking the time to share your experience with this brush. With certain hair types, including goat hair, it's important to actively remove loose hairs before you begin painting. There are several ways you can remove loose hairs from the brush before beginning work — one is just to gently flick the tuft back and forth with a finger, which will cause loose hair to pop up for removal. However, please know that once the brush is broken in, the shedding should stop. If it doesn't, please give us a call at 1-800-723-2787, and our Customer Care Team will take good care of you!

My students and I use these bamboo brushes in my classroom to paint glaze on pottery. They work great, they hold a lot of glaze and make painting it on easy. Recently many of my students have wanted to do more detailed painting with their glazes, and regular acrylic paint brushes just don't hold as much paint. The smaller size 0 and 4 brushes work great, maintain a fine point and hold more glaze, so it's easier to paint clean continuous lines.
